title: 106_hr4738
content: The "Immigrant Labor Policy Review Act" establishes the High Level Commission on Immigrant Labor Policy to address labor shortages in various industries in the United States. The Commission's duties include reviewing and proposing policies to secure sufficient workers and improve the economy and standard of living. The Commission will study the impact of Federal immigration policy on labor markets in the US, including the supply of labor, reliance on temporary workers, statutory caps on nonimmigrant workers, and employment of unlawfully present aliens. The Commission will consult with various groups and organizations to study the impact of Federal immigration policy on labor markets in the US, including the effectiveness of labor policies in stopping illegal immigration and any other necessary subjects for preparing reports. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate. The President consults with various officials for appointments. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The director and staff of the Commission may be appointed without regard to certain civil service laws, and the chairperson may appoint additional personnel as needed. The chairperson of the Commission may hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the maximum GS-15 pay. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 7. POWERS. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to obtain official data from Federal agencies, use the United States mails, request administrative support services, and contract with government and private agencies for research and services. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission must submit an interim report within 6 months of the Act's enactment, evaluating the effectiveness of Federal immigration and labor laws in protecting jobs for citizens, preventing exploitation of immigrant workers, and reducing illegal border crossings. The Commission will evaluate the impact of statutory limitations on immigrant and nonimmigrant entry, recent border measures, and Federal alien labor laws on economic performance in various sectors within the United States. The Commission will prepare a final report with updated findings and recommendations to address illegal border crossings, unlawful employment of aliens, and protection of workers in specific sectors like nursing, health care, apparel, and information technology. The Commission will explore expanding the agricultural guest worker program to industries such as tourism, construction, nursing, healthcare, apparel, and information technology. Additionally, they will provide recommendations to improve Federal immigration and labor laws. SEC. 9. TERMINATION. The Commission will terminate 6 months after submitting its final report. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for carrying out this Act are authorized to be appropriated and will remain available until expended.
